webTitle: Vodafone dips as analysts tip new takeover targets

fields.standfirst: Societe Generale says company could be interested in Spain or parts of Liberty Global
fields.body:
Vodafone has long been the centre of takeover speculation - both as predator and prey - and this has only increased since the announcement of the $130bn sale of its US wireless stake to partner Verizon.

Although the prospect of Verizon bidding for Vodafone has receded, AT&T is the latest favourite to take a tilt at the UK mobile group.

As for Vodafone's targets, analysts at Societe Generale have tipped a couple of prospects, although they believe cherry picking parts of various businesses is more likely than outright takeovers. They identified Spain's Ono and US group Liberty Global as possible prospects, saying:

We estimate Vodafone has about £16bn (€19bn) for potential M&A transactions. Given its strategy to become a leading total communications provider, we think there is good strategic rationale for Vodafone to strike a deal with Ono.
[But] with market dynamics in Spain remaining difficult and Vodafone potentially having to pay a significant premium to acquire Ono, we think that Vodafone is more likely to pursue a strategy it considers to be less risky in Spain compared to an outright takeover of Ono. Following the recent closure of the Kabel Deutschland transaction, Vodafone's immediate focus will also be on the integration effort with Kabel, and ensuring that its first major transaction in the European cable sector is a success.
Ultimately, to the extent Vodafone wants to reconsider deals in Spain, we think that Jazztel could be a more likely target than Ono.

SocGen also notes speculation Vodafone could be interested in Liberty Global, but thinks an all-in bid is unlikely:

We expect that Vodafone is likely to 'cherry-pick' from the Liberty Global basket those assets that offer the best synergies with its own businesses and limited regulatory hurdles. Liberty Global markets where Vodafone has a mobile-only presence such as the Netherlands and Romania are likely to be first on the list, in our view. Other markets such as Ireland could be next given that Vodafone has only a limited fixed line presence here and regulatory hurdles should hence be surmountable

.

Vodafone shares have dipped 0.8p to 228.5p.

webTitle: Elderly care: is Jeremy Hunt right to call for an Asian solution?

fields.standfirst: The health secretary says families should be looking after their elderly relatives, but it may not be that simple
fields.body:
How the UK copes with an increasingly lonely population of over-65s is a key economic and social question, and it is great that the health secretary has thought to mention it in his latest speech.

Jeremy Hunt has searched earnestly for an answer. The British way of ageing is deeply flawed, he says, concluding that adopting the Asian way of caring is the answer.

The first problem with calls for Britons to be more Asian when it comes to care, just like injunctions to adopt German rigour in business and the Swedish way of family life, is that we are British and culturally we behave very differently.

But let's set that aside and ask whether the Asian solution is the answer.

Firstly, the responsibility for caring, outside state-organised schemes, often falls to women – and usually to the middle-aged mother who is also still mainly responsible for bringing up children. Most caring within state and private institutions is also carried out by women, but they are paid and gain some economic independence. Caring when it means giving up work is a form of servitude that leaves many women deeply unhappy.

Closer to home, both Germany and Italy have low birth rates associated with traditional family duties. Until recently German women were almost obliged to look after their children until they went to school at seven. Their response was to stop having more than one child. Pressure to keep the birthrate low is even more intense in Italy, where mothers are also expected to look after parents and in-laws. Italy avoided bankruptcy in the financial crash largely because its welfare state is largely conducted by an unpaid workforce of guilt-tripped women. Having children has become a minority occupation.

Secondly, the Asian example is associated with an agrarian economy, where family is close by. Indonesia, the Philippines, Malaysia and China are rapidly urbanising and confronting the same issues as us.

Consider this brief extract from an article in the Jakarta Post:

Cumi Solechah, a 65-year-old widow, says she did not think her senior years would be spent in a nursing home.
"Life is just a mystery. You don't know where it will lead you," Umi told the Jakarta Post during a recent visit to Budi Mulia 4 nursing home in Radio Dalam, South Jakarta. Umi, who worked with the Indonesian embassy in Washington DC for 10 years, recalled serving Indonesian diplomats including former ambassadors Soesilo Soedarman and Arifin Siregar. Her life changed when she had to return in 1998 to treat her sick mother. "I spent nearly all my riches treating my mom before she died," said Umi, who worked in the US from 1989 to 1997. Her husband then passed away. Umi did not elaborate on why she went to a nursing home aside from saying: "I was abandoned by my brothers and sisters despite my contributions to them."

Is this the Asian example Hunt wants us to emulate?

Indonesia's National Commission for the Elderly said only 3.9% of the country's elderly in 2006 could rely on their monthly pension fund.

The commission said this drove about 50% of elderly women to rely on their children and their partners, compared with 29% of elderly men.

The Post reported one nursing home head as saying that in many cases the elderly were abandoned by their children or other family members if they had a low income or health issue such as Alzheimer's.

Geoff Mulgan, the boss of the government-funded ideas charity Nesta, says we need to create a volunteer workforce to bring the poorer and weaker people among our 12 million over-65s together to alleviate poverty and tackle loneliness.

In 2009 I argued for a programme of national service for the over-65s. Mulgan wants a voluntary scheme, and mine would not be compulsory but with elements of coercion and guilt to spur participation.

This system would build on existing networks and draw on charities and the latest thinking among local authorities for co-operative ventures. We don't need to be Asian to be kind and set aside a little time for community service. But we do need a little encouragement and a scheme that we can feel comfortable joining.

webTitle: Liberum examines companies exposed to UK government policy

fields.standfirst: Support services, utilities, transport and construction groups all in the line of fire
fields.body:
With Ed Miliband's recent call for energy prices to be frozen - followed shortly by huge hikes by leading companies SSE and British Gas - analysts at Liberum have taken a look at companies most exposed to changes in government policy.

They said:

The tentacles of government are growing – price fixing at utilities muted by Miliband, interference about speed of payment at the constructors, growing politics surrounding outsourcing, pressure on Royal Bank of Scotland, risk of increased transport regulation. We highlight stocks with the largest exposure to government 'meddling'.

Liberum split them into sectors, starting with support services which is already under pressure after investigations into government contracts run by G4S and Serco:

The current stasis in outsourcing looks likely to extend into a prolonged pre/post election hiatus. The implications of the ongoing investigation (and the likelihood of negative headlines) spread beyond Serco (hold) and result in our cautious sector stance – Mitie (sell), Babcock (hold).

In the construction sector, Liberum said government initiatives to support small suppliers are putting pressure on cash flows, although a recovery in volumes and alternative funding could provide an offset.

Possible measures to cool the London housing market - Liberum suggests a tax on foreigner buyers if not primary home, 50% of new build schemes must be UK buyers - could hit Capital & Counties Properties.

Utilities of course face the threat of price caps, while the media awaits the final outcome of the Leveson enquiry. In aerospace and defence, Liberum said:

Government attempts to boost UK exports to £1tr by 2020 are highly relevant given the defence industry's export potential. However, there is risk of negative meddling surrounding big ticket platforms, such as the new aircraft carriers built by BAE Systems and Babcock.

On transport, Liberum said FirstGroup, Go-Ahead, National Express and Stagecoach are all exposed to the tougher regulation proposed by Labour.

Finally Royal Bank of Scotland could be forced to split into a good and bad bank.

webTitle: Wonga buys German payment firm BillPay as global expansion continues

fields.standfirst: Controversial lender purchases company which lets people pay in instalments for items bought online
fields.body:
Payday lender Wonga has continued its global expansion with the purchase of German payment firm BillPay.

The controversial online lender, which charges an annual interest rate on UK loans of more than 5,000%, said the deal "significantly accelerates our development into a broad-based, digital finance group".

The German firm lets people pay for items bought online with a range of different payment methods, including instalment credit. Founded in 2009, it has around 2 million users and more than 3,500 online partners in Germany, Austria, Switzerland and the Netherlands.

Wonga has a similar PayLater service that allows customers to spread the cost of items up to £1,000 over three monthly payments in return for an upfront fee, but it only has around 20 retailers on board so far.

It said the purchase of BillPay would help to expand the service, and help its development internationally.

Wonga's chief executive, Errol Damelin, said: "The combined Wonga and BillPay business will consolidate our position as a pioneer in the financial revolution, offering customers a range of bold new payment and credit solutions for the modern world.

"As well as giving Wonga a presence in Europe's second largest online retail market, this deal continues our ongoing transformation into a fully international, digital finance business with operations across three continents and more than 3 million customers."

The founder of BillPay, Nelson Holzner, will remain with the group. He said: "All of us at BillPay are delighted we are joining forces with such a large and innovative group as Wonga. We feel our services and ethos are entirely complementary and we look forward to working with them."

Wonga has already expanded into several markets around the world and now offers short-term, high cost credit in South Africa, Poland and Canada. Earlier this year it also bought a Spanish payday lender, Credito Pocket, and a stake in the Indian firm Nahar Credits Private.

It recently quietly rebranded its Wonga for Business offer in the UK to Everline.com

The bulk of its lending , however, is still made to UK consumers. In 2012 they accounted for 3.8m of its 4m loans over the year, amounting to a total of £1.2bn.

The news of Wonga's expansion came as home credit provider Provident Financial said that it was also planning to expand its online presence as revenues from its core doorstep lending business fall.

The firm has been trialling online loans of between £100 and £300 repaid over 13 or 26 weeks, and said in its interim statement that the service had "proved capable of delivering the group's target returns".

It added that online credit of up to 12 months in duration would appeal to customers who had been declined its Vanquis Bank credit card, and other consumers who did not qualify for a card but would not use doorstep loans.

"To address these opportunities, a new separately branded online product will be launched shortly," the company said.

webTitle: Bonmarché prepares stock exchange flotation

fields.standfirst: Fashion chain aimed at women over 50 says it is poised for growth as the number of older women rises
fields.body:
Bonmarché, the fashion chain aimed at women over 50, is preparing to float on the London Stock Exchange in November, in a further sign of surging activity on equity markets.

The retailer, best known for its plus-size ranges, announced on Friday that it planned to sell shares on the alternative investment market (Aim) next month, telling investors it was poised for growth as the number of older women is set to rise.

Bonmarché is the latest high street retailer to eye the stock market, with House of Fraser and the furniture store DFS also rumoured to be seeking a listing, and the entrepreneur Clive Coombes bidding to revive the Comet brand and float the chain of electrical goods shops on Aim, a junior LSE market. Royal Mail was privatised this month, the estate agent Foxtons made its stock market debut recently and the property website Zoopla is also considering going public.

The Bonmarché listing would represent a remarkable turnaround in fortunes for the Wakefield-based company, after it was sold with the loss of 1,400 jobs at the start of last year, as it became another victim of fierce high street competition. The private equity firm Sun European Partners, which also owns the women's fashion chain Jacques Vert and the bedding retailer Dreams, bought the business from the Peacock Group in a deal that allowed them to close more than 100 unprofitable Bonmarché stores.

Under its chief executive, Beth Butterwick, the tills have been ringing again, with 13% sales growth in the six months to the end of September, compared with the same period last year. Bonmarché claims to have 1.8 million active members and 6.5 million people registered on its Bonus Club reward scheme. As well as refitting some of its 264 shops, the group is now scouting for new locations and plans to open stores in garden centres as part of a tie-up with the Garden Centre Group.

Since Sun European Partners took over, the company has earned £9.1m on an income measure that counts earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation. Butterwick said: "We are confident that our competitive position and loyal customer base means that we are well placed to capitalise on this attractive and fast growing niche of the retail sector."

webTitle: Prudential leads FTSE higher after boost from Asian rival

fields.bodyText: Prudential is leading the way in a positive market, following an upbeat statement overnight from Asian rival AIA. AIA reported record quarterly results and said its new business rose by 26%. With Prudential's strong exposure to the region, its shares have jumped 42p to £12.56. The insurance sector was also helped by reports that an EU capital requirement could be eased compared to the initial version sought by regulators. Back with Asia, strong Chinese growth figures showing third quarter GDP up by 7.8% has helped support the market, which continues to greet the deal to resolve the US budget and debt ceiling crisis with some caution. Dealers are concerned the situation will reoccur early next year when the new deadlines are reached. The FTSE 100 is currently up 20.71 points at 6596.87, helped by a strong performance on Wall Street where the S&P 500 hit a new high.
